posts.name: Elliot Smith
posts.cooked:
DonDino:

Could you please give us links to some of them so we can have a look?

In my above message, I have enumerated several specific complaints which you can easily verify for yourself. Specifically, I complained:

<<The structure of the Signal organization is opaque, the names of the people on the board of directors are not published, there is no contact information for how to file complaints about employee conduct. There are no published standards of behavior, there is no published code of conduct, no mission statement, nothing.>>

I think that it is reasonable to expect that an organization that can not address these specific complaints, will also have difficulty addressing other specific complaints.

I have not kept links to my various specific application complaints over the years. I frequently changed accounts and I have lost track of my old github accounts, etc.

However, you are welcome to click on and view the history of my present forum account here, you can see where I complain about losing access to all my Signal data, and you can see where the forum mod who replies has no understanding of what I’m talking about. Hell, the forum mod can’t even begin to accept a suggestion to clarify the UI of the forum its self.

What you don’t see in my forum post history for this present account is where I tried to create a new post specifically about the problem of losing access to all my Signal data, and my new post was rejected as being a duplicate of an existing post, even though it was not a duplicate. This rejection was simply an effort to annoy me.

I think for some forum mods, the highest priority is to tell users that they are wrong, to psychologically gaslight users. There are people with such psychology, and of course, such people will gravitate towards positions of power such as forum mods for the same reason that certain people gravitate towards of power in, say, certain religious organizations. Whenever you give people power without oversight and accountability, you will eventually attract some abusive people…

Speaking of lack of accountability, the forum mod who rejected my post as being a “duplicate” was allowed to reject my post anonymously, using an anonymous administrator account, so I can not even give you the name of the moderator who did this… This lack of accountability suggests an organization with contempt for users and contempt for the organization’s own mission.

As for failure of the encryption implementation, I’m sure the encryption its self is sound, but the implementation… Yes it’s not good to have your Signal messages delivered without encryption… But Signal’s psychologically abusive impulse to always gaslight and blame users means that when my Signal messages are delivered without encryption, it is my fault.

Don’t get me wrong, the Signal problems that persist for years obviously affect a relatively small proportion of the users. These problems are more or less edge cases, such as strange behaviors that happen when you lose your wifi connection at just the right moment. When large numbers of people report a problem, or when the developers personally experience a problem, then the problem is more likely to be fixed. However, when a problem is reported by only one or two people, then the problem is very likely to be ignored by Signal’s abusive staff who delights in gaslighting users and telling users that they are wrong.

The inability to fix problem is not unique to Signal. When a bridge collapses, or a when a ship full of fertilizer explodes in a port, we almost always find out that warning were ignored. It is difficult for an organization to be competent. It is just sad to see that Signal, an organization whose decisions affect the safety and security of so many people, has a development process and a bug reporting process that is no more careful or responsible than we see with any other random software such as we might expect to see with a small video game application.

So again, in above comments, I reported several very specific problems:

<<The structure of the Signal organization is opaque, the names of the people on the board of directors are not published, there is no contact information for how to file complaints about employee conduct. There are no published standards of behavior, there is no published code of conduct, no mission statement, nothing.>>

Fixing these specific organization problems won’t directly and immediately improve the Signal application’s development lifecycle, but fixing these problems would be the first step to fixing the application. I have some limited idea of who is providing executive direction over the Signal organization, and what can I say… I think they have good intentions, but hey, Bill & Melinda Gates also had good intentions with their efforts to restructure the American education system… Having good intentions is not enough… To be successful and effective, organizations need to be democratic, and there needs to be accountability at every level of the organization. At the end of the day, Signal is run by millionaires with no accountability.
